title: 109_hr1981
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Adult Day Care Services Act of 2005". Congress finds that adult day care services provide essential support to seniors and their caregivers, helping to keep seniors in their family homes. A significant number of workers provide elder care, and the number of households involved in caregiving is expected to increase. The pool of potential family caregivers, primarily women, provides an estimated $257 billion in "free" services annually. Caregiving families have lower incomes, with caregivers losing $659,139 in wages and benefits over a lifetime. The loss in productivity in US businesses due to caregivers ranges from $11 billion to $29 billion annually. Adult day care centers nationwide offer quality health options for the elderly population. The aging baby boomer generation will increase the need for health options for the elderly population. SEC. 3. MEDICARE COVERAGE OF SUBSTITUTE ADULT DAY CARE SERVICES. This section amends the Social Security Act to include coverage for substitute adult day care services under Medicare. "Medicare coverage now includes substitute adult day care services." Medicare now covers substitute adult day care services, which include items and services provided by an adult day care facility as part of a plan that substitutes services from a home health agency. This includes transportation, meals, and supervised activities. The adult day care facility offers programs to promote physical and mental health, including a medication management program to minimize inappropriate drug use and adverse interactions. An adult day care facility must meet specific standards set by the Secretary to ensure quality care and safety for individuals receiving services. The Secretary has the authority to waive the surety bond requirement if a comparable bond is provided under State law. Payment for substitute adult day care services under the home health prospective payment system is addressed in the Social Security Act. Home health agencies can provide these services through arrangements with adult day care facilities. Conforming amendments have been made to relevant sections of the Act. The Social Security Act addresses payment for substitute adult day care services under the home health prospective payment system. The Secretary will determine payment rates for these services provided under the plan of care. The Secretary estimates payment amounts for home health services other than substitute adult day care services under a specified plan of care. The total payment for substitute adult day care services is based on the estimated amount payable for other home health services. No payment is made for substitute adult day care services under certain limitations. The curr_chunk discusses limitations on payment for substitute adult day care services under the Social Security Act, specifying that an adult day care facility must accept the payment provided for home health services as payment in full. This is in line with the consolidated billing amendment in section 1862(a) of the Act. The curr_chunk amends the Social Security Act to include substitute adult day care services for payment under specific conditions. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to items and services furnished on or after January 1, 2006. The Secretary may terminate the demonstration project for medical adult day care services established under a specific section, ensuring no interruption in services for individuals. The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 is amended by removing a subsection related to a demonstration program.
